comments.body:
It exposes port 111 as udp, but the comment above mentioned as tcp.
Both rc and svc use tcp instead of udp.

Anyway, I could this updated nfs example worked in my GKE cluster, I wonder rpcbind is not used?
rpcbind uses both tcp and udp port 111. It has to be running and accessible to make mount and nfs work.

Sorry, I missed that both 111/tcp and 111/udp is exposed in the image.

However, it seems that only 111/tcp is defined in rc and svc.
https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/22665/files#diff-2dd0818b520821f3d109443e9bc79424R23
https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/22665/files#diff-224bfcd27f055737f9893725d1b72c7dR12
Is it OK?
ServicePort and ContainerPort regard ports as TCP if protocol is omitted.
http://kubernetes.io/docs/api-reference/v1/definitions/#_v1_serviceport
http://kubernetes.io/docs/api-reference/v1/definitions/#_v1_containerport
yes, tcp is good enough. NFS clients will try one transport first, then falls through to the other if the first transport is not accessible.
